0	In mathematics , a Janet basis is a normal form for systems of linear homogeneous partial differential equations -LRB- PDEs -RRB- that removes the inherent arbitrariness of any such system .	normal form	canonical form
1	It was introduced in 1920 by Maurice Janet .	Maurice Janet	Maurice Janet
2	It was first called the Janet basis by Fritz Schwarz in 1998 .

5	The left hand sides of such systems of equations may be considered as differential polynomials of a ring , and Janet 's normal form as a special basis of the ideal that they generate .	normal form	canonical form
6	By abuse of language , this terminology will be applied both to the original system and the ideal of differential polynomials generated by the left hand sides .
7	A Janet basis is the predecessor of a Gröbner basis introduced by Bruno Buchberger for polynomial ideals .	Gröbner basis	Gröbner basis	Bruno Buchberger	Bruno Buchberger
8	In order to generate a Janet basis for any given system of linear pde 's a ranking of its derivatives must be provided ; then the corresponding Janet basis is unique .

10	In order to generate a Loewy decomposition of a system of linear pde 's its Janet basis must be determined first .	Loewy decomposition	Loewy decomposition

0	Hourglass Federalism is a theory about Canadian economic geography and political economy that has been promoted by Professor Thomas J. Courchene of Queen 's University .	Federalism	Federalism	Thomas J. Courchene	Tom Courchene
1	The thesis he proposes is that federal cutbacks of provincial transfers to social services since 1995 has caused significant fiscal imbalances .	fiscal imbalances	Fiscal imbalance in Canada

2	These funding cuts forced the provinces to make cutbacks in nearly every provincial jurisdiction , except healthcare because cutting healthcare funding would be political suicide , but this left almost every other provincial jurisdiction , including cities which are creations of the provinces , with reduced and often insufficient funding .

3	However , in the meantime , the federal government has been providing greater funds to social programs but they have been bypassing the provinces and giving the money directly to cities and/or citizens .
4	This allows the federal government to fund provincial jurisdictions directly causing the provinces to become `` the squeezed middle of the division-of-powers hourglass '' .

7	Courchene defines Hourglass Federalism as `` Ottawa 's use of the spending power and other instruments to fiscally starve the provinces and then to make an end run around them to deal directly with cities and citizens alike , leaving the provinces of the squeezed middle of the division-of-powers hourglass '' .	Federalism	Federalism
